stories.text:
...by which I mean, open-source projects that aren't tied to a full organization with a budget for these things, but still want to present nicely. Esp programming languages, libraries, etc.

Did you design it yourself? Contract a designer with your own money to do some mock-ups? Did you use an off-the-shelf template?
stories.title: Ask HN: Who designed the website for your software project?

stories.text:
Hey, everyone! This is not a rant or an amusing story or a snarky comeback (for once). It was inspired by a post yesterday.

I have an idea that would cost me some money: a "steelmanning" educational institute. It would become a 501(c)(3) eventually, but of course it costs some money to get there. We would teach people how to do it, possibly with contests where experienced lawyers, judges, and debate coaches judge the contestants. What do you think?
stories.title: Ask HN: A Steelmanning Institute

stories.text:
Their parents are interested in having them get a sense of possible career paths.

I have never met the kid before. I honestly don't even know what this entails - I'm worried writing code is not a very fun spectator sport, so I probably won't walk him through whatever tedious piece of code I'm trying to write. I'm thinking I'll give him a quick overview of what the company does and then maybe just chat about programming with him.

I'm also considering giving him a very easy coding task in Python - not for work, just to keep him busy? - but it's difficult to gauge what's appropriate here.

Any suggestions or advice from people who have done something similar in the past?
stories.title: Ask HN: I will have a 14-year old shadow me at work â€“ any advice?
